name: Lombard Invasion of Italy
description: Lombards led by Alboin enter Italy and conquer regions north of the Po; immediate foundation of the Friulian duchy; capture of Pavia

name: Assassination of Alboin
description: Alboin is assassinated (conspiracy of his wife Rosmunda, possibly with Byzantine support)

name: Reign of Clefi
description: Reign of Clefi: massacre of Roman nobles, king's murder probably by Byzantine conspiracy

name: Interregnum Period
description: For a decade the Lombards do not elect a king

name: Reign of Autari
description: Reign of Autari, who fights against the Franks who had invaded Trentino

name: Papacy of Gregory the Great
description: Papacy of Gregory the Great: the pope assumes a prominent role in government and defense of the city and enters into contact with Lombard kings

name: Reign of Agilulf and Theodelinda
description: Reign of Agilulf and Theodelinda: invasion of central Italy; first truce with the Byzantines (598); conquest of Padua and Monselice; Theodelinda founds S. Giovanni di Monza

name: Schism of the Three Chapters
description: Schism of the Three Chapters, which sees the diocese of Aquileia in disagreement with Rome and Constantinople

name: Avar Invasion of Friuli
description: The Avars invade Friuli and sack Cividale

name: Foundation of S. Colombano di Bobbio
description: Foundation of the monastery of S. Colombano di Bobbio

name: Reign of Adaloald
description: Reign of Adaloald, son of Agilulf and Theodelinda

name: Reign of Arioald
description: Reign of Arioald, Duke of Turin, poorly documented by sources

name: Reign of Rotari and the Edict
description: Reign of Rotari: issuance of the Edict (643); conquests of Liguria and part of eastern Veneto (first destruction of Oderzo). After him reigns his son Rodoaldo, but only for a few months

name: Reign of Aripert
description: Reign of Aripert: was son of Gundoald Duke of Asti and nephew of Theodelinda; under him there would have been the definitive conversion to Catholicism of the Lombards

name: Division of the Kingdom
description: The kingdom is divided between the two sons of Aripert, Godepert and Pertarit

name: Reign of Grimoald
description: Reign of Grimoald: Duke of Benevento, of Friulian origin, seizes power by killing Godepert, while Pertarit flees first to the Avars, then to the Franks; fall of Oderzo and complete conquest of eastern Veneto, while Byzantine military power takes refuge in the lagoon; the king adds some chapters to the edict

name: Reign of Pertarit
description: Reign of Pertarit: becomes king by killing Garipald, son of Grimoald; Cunipert, son of the king, is associated with the kingdom; rebellion of Alahis Duke of Trento, who is then pardoned and also assumes the duchy of Brescia

name: Reign of Cunipert
description: Reign of Cunipert: new rebellion of Alahis, defeated and killed; synod of Pavia (698) and end of the schism of the Three Chapters

name: Synod of Rome
description: Synod in Rome condemning monothelitism. First true peace between the Lombard kingdom and the Byzantine empire

name: Foundation of Monasteries
description: Foundation of the monasteries of S. Maria di Farfa and S. Vincenzo al Volturno (ca.)

name: Aripert II Seizes Power
description: Aripert II, son of the Duke of Turin and nephew of King Godepert, seizes the throne by killing little Liutpert, son of Cunipert, and defeating his supporters

name: Rise of Liutprand
description: Ansprand, one of Liutpert's supporters, together with his son Liutprand, defeats Aripert II and becomes king. Dies a few months later and Liutprand is elected king of the Lombards

name: Liutprand's Legal Reforms
description: First addition of chapters to the edict by Liutprand (followed by fourteen other additions in the years between 717 and 735)

name: Iconoclastic Crisis
description: Iconoclastic crisis: Leo III imposes iconoclastic doctrine at Constantinople; Byzantine Italy rebels and independent dukes are elected in the Venetiae, at Ravenna and at Naples; the pope leads the opposition, which is religious but also political

name: Liutprand's Conquests
description: Liutprand's conquests in Emilia and the Pentapolis; submission of the rebel dukes of Spoleto and Benevento; journey to Rome of the king who places the royal insignia on the tomb of St. Peter

name: Lombard Expansion and Frankish Alliance
description: The Lombards led by Hildeprand, nephew of the king, temporarily occupy Ravenna; Liutprand intervenes in Provence in aid of Charles Martel against the Arabs; previously he had adopted with the cutting of hair his son Pippin; later, the king having fallen ill, Hildeprand is elected king; recovered, Liutprand associates his nephew to the throne (ca.)

name: Papacy of Gregory III
description: Papacy of Gregory III. First appeal to the Franks, which falls on deaf ears

name: Refoundation of Montecassino
description: Refoundation of Montecassino (ca.)

name: Papacy of Zachary
description: Papacy of Zachary

name: Peace Agreements
description: Meetings at Terni and Pavia between Liutprand and Zachary, which result in peace agreements

name: Death of Liutprand
description: Death of Liutprand. Hildeprand is deposed and Ratchis, Duke of Friuli, becomes king

name: Reign of Ratchis
description: Reign of Ratchis: continuation of the Edict; military expeditions in the Pentapolis; abdicates in favor of his brother Astulf and becomes a monk at Montecassino

name: First Phase of Astulf's Reign
description: First phase of Astulf's reign: additions to the Edict (745 and 750); conquest of Ravenna and the Exarchate

name: Papacy of Stephen II
description: Papacy of Stephen II, who calls the Franks for help against Astulf; renews the anointing of Pippin and obtains the promissio carisiaca (754)

name: First Frankish Intervention
description: First military intervention of Pippin in Italy, who defeats Astulf and forces him to 'return' to the pope the Byzantine territories he had occupied

name: Second Frankish Intervention
description: Second military intervention of Pippin in Italy. Death of Astulf

name: Reign of Desiderius
description: Desiderius is elected king of the Lombards. Does not deliver to the pope the occupied Byzantine territories. Invasion of the Pentapolis

name: Adelchis Associated to Throne
description: Adelchis, son of Desiderius, is associated to the throne by his father

name: Foundation of S. Salvatore di Brescia
description: Foundation of S. Salvatore di Brescia by Desiderius and his wife Ansa. Their daughter Anselperga is abbess

name: Papacy of Adrian I
description: Papacy of Adrian I. Again asks Desiderius in vain for the delivery of the occupied Byzantine territories. Agreement with the Franks

name: Charlemagne Conquers Lombard Kingdom
description: Charlemagne (768-814) conquers the Lombard kingdom and becomes rex Langobardorum

name: Lombard Rebellion and Suppression
description: Having failed the project of a general uprising, only Friuli and Veneto rebel against the Franks under the command of the Friulian duke Rotcauso and, defeated, suffer harsh repression

name: Pippin becomes King of Lombards
description: Carloman, son of Charlemagne, is baptized with the name of Pippin and becomes king of the Lombards

name: Constitutum Constantini
description: Drafting of the Constitutum Constantini

name: Papacy of Leo III
description: Papacy of Leo III

name: Defeat of the Avars
description: Pippin, king of the Lombards, defeats the Avars and destroys the ring

name: Charlemagne Crowned Emperor
description: Charlemagne is crowned emperor in Rome at St. Peter's by Pope Leo III

name: Death of Pippin
description: Death of Pippin
